title: Chapter 319
content: # Chapter 319 Grid's jaw tightened as he studied Piaro. The man stood there in ragged farmer's clothing, not a scratch on him despite the barrage Grid had unleashed. *At least level 400.* He didn't need the Great Lord's Sword to confirm it. The numbers spoke for themselves. Every strike he'd landed had done nothing. Zero damage. Against an unarmored target. *A hundred level gap. Maybe more.* The disparity crushed down on him like a physical weight. A hundred levels wasn't just a number. It was a chasm. Stats doubled, tripled. Skills evolved into something unrecognizable. The system's level compensation only went so far. By every logical calculation, his odds of winning were nonexistent. But logic had limits. *I don't need logic. I have items.* The thought steadied him. Items were the great equalizer. The system's balance was a joke when you had the right gear. For players scraping by with marketplace trash, that imbalance was torture. For Grid, it was salvation. Piaro wore farming tools. Rare rated at best. Old cloth that wouldn't stop a kitchen knife. *The matchup favors me.* Grid had faced down a legendary farmer before. Witnessed the absurd strength firsthand. But a farmer was still a farmer. How could that compare to a Sword Saint? The class that stood at the pinnacle of all swordsmen? *I'll drag you back to the sword, old man.* He activated Item Disassembly. The four golden blades hovering near him shimmered and dissolved. The Water Clan King's Tears separated out, each one a perfect teardrop of crystallized magic. He pocketed those. The rest, twenty-seven pieces of pure pavranium, went straight into the furnace. Heat washed over his face. The metal began to glow. Khan appeared at his elbow, squinting into the furnace. The young blacksmiths crowded behind him, jostling for position. *What's he making this time?* They watched Grid's hands move. Measured. Precise. He pulled a section of clay toward him and began shaping a mold. The young blacksmiths frowned. Khan tilted his head. *That's not a blade.* It wasn't a spear either. Not an arrowhead or an axe. The shape was too organic. Too familiar. Grid pressed his palm into the clay, adjusting the curves with a sculptor's focus. Five times. Five perfect impressions. *His hands?* Ttang! Ttang! Grid's hammer rang against the mold frames, sealing them shut. The molten pavranium in the furnace had taken on a liquid gold sheen. He lifted the crucible with both hands and poured. Gold flowed into each cavity. Steam hissed where it touched moisture. The smell of hot metal filled the smithy. *** Jishuka wiped blood off her bowstring and glanced at the entrance to the tenth vampire city. Same dark halls. Same Gothic architecture. Same endless waves of bloodsuckers. "We're running the same five cities over and over." She notched another arrow. "When's Grid coming back?" Pon drove his spear through a vampire's chest and kicked the corpse away. "Two days. Maybe three." "He's got something important going on." Regas crushed a vampire's skull with his bare fist. "Said it's urgent." "More important than the experience buff?" Yura's magic bullets tore through three targets in rapid succession. "We only have twenty-five days left." "He made Chris a greatsword last week." Vantner's shield caught a blood spear mid-flight. "What else could he be crafting?" "Maybe Chris screwed him over?" "No." Lauel's voice was calm as he redirected a blood wave with his qigong. "He said he's making the ultimate overgeared item." Everyone paused mid-swing. "The ultimate what?" Swords made sense. Spears. Bows. Those were weapons. Fighting tools. But the 'ultimate overgeared item' was too vague. "Did he figure out instant Item Combination?" Zednos's wind magic scattered a group of approaching vampires. "That's…" Lauel hesitated. "Not impossible. Pagma's Descendant has too many hidden abilities. And Grid exploits every one of them." The Overgeared members exchanged glances. None of them could predict what Grid was building. *** The molds cooled. Grid cracked them open one by one. Golden hands emerged, still warm to the touch. He set them on the workbench in a neat row. Five perfect replicas of his own hands. Down to the fingerprints. He stepped back and activated the pavranium. The hands floated. Hovering at chest height. Fingers spread wide like blooming flowers. *Yes!* Grid's mind raced through applications. Five shields orbiting him in combat. Five swords striking in perfect coordination. Enemies wouldn't know where to block. He'd be untouchable. Khan gasped. The young blacksmiths stumbled backward, staring at the floating hands like they'd witnessed a miracle. Grid pulled his weapons from inventory. Failure. Iyarugt. Grid's Greatsword. The Ideal Dagger. The Divine Shield. He laid them on the workbench and pointed. "Equip these!" The five hands shot forward. And slammed into the weapons like drunken birds hitting windows. Metal clattered against stone. The Ideal Dagger skittered across the floor. Grid's Greatsword landed flat with a dull clang. Grid stared. *What…* The hands hovered back into formation. Palms open. Fingers rigid. Utterly useless. "Grab them!" Grid's voice cracked. "You fold your fingers! Like this!" He demonstrated. Closed fist. Open palm. Closed fist. Open palm. The pavranium didn't move. "Are you serious right now?!" Silence. Grid made the motions again. Slower. More exaggerated. "Rock! Paper! Scissors! Do it!" The hands floated there. Mocking him with their stillness. "Why won't you move?!" The young blacksmiths shifted uncomfortably. One of them whispered to another. "Is Lord Grid… okay?" "Should we get help?" Khan shook his head and sighed. "It's been a while since I've seen this side of him." *** Grid forced himself to stop yelling. He pulled up the item information. > **[Hand Model of a Legendary Blacksmith]** > > **Attack Power:** 22 > **Weight:** 15 > > A model of the hands of the legendary blacksmith Grid. > > It is made of pavranium, so it can move by itself. > > If the open palms hit the opponent's cheeks, the provocation effect is activated. He read it twice. Then a third time. *Oh.* The realization hit like cold water. Hands were complex. Joints within joints. Twenty-seven bones per hand. Tendons. Ligaments. Muscles. All of it working together to produce the fine motor control that let him grip a sword or thread a needle. These pavranium hands had none of that. They were solid blocks shaped like hands. No internal structure. No articulation. Expensive, useless paperweights. "Shit." He needed to understand human anatomy. The full biomechanics of a hand. Every joint. Every pivot point. Otherwise, he was just making sculptures. Grid pulled up his interface and searched for reference materials. "An encyclopedia won't help." He rubbed his face. "I need actual medical texts." Medical texts required comprehension. Reading ability. An IQ above room temperature. Grid's hands trembled. *Why does a game require me to understand anatomy?!* The old Grid would have raged. Would have screamed about how games were supposed to be fun, not homework. Would have demanded the developers make things simpler for stupid people. But he wasn't that person anymore. If he wanted the God Hands, he'd earn them. No shortcuts. Grid took a breath and logged out. *** Shin Youngwoo sat at his desk with three browser windows open. Medical encyclopedia. Anatomy diagrams. A tutorial video on hand biomechanics. *The thumb has two joints. The fingers have three. Tendons on the front and back. Nerves and blood vessels on the sides.* He scribbled notes on scrap paper. Drew crude diagrams. Rewatched the video when he forgot something. His memory was garbage. Always had been. Information slipped through his brain like water through a sieve. So he repeated everything five times. Ten times. Until it stuck. *I can't forget this after logging back in.* Technically, the Creation skill would handle most of the work. The system's correction function was powerful. He just needed the basic framework. A rough blueprint. But Youngwoo kept studying. Kept memorizing. He wanted perfect hands. Not functional hands. Not passable hands. Perfect. "Youngwoo! Trash day!" His mother's voice cut through his focus like a cleaver through meat. "I'm studying!" Youngwoo shouted back. "For the first time in five years!" She always did this. Always picked the exact moment he was focused to interrupt. Homework? Interrupted. Studying for an exam? Interrupted. Trying to learn hand anatomy at three in the morning? Interrupted. *Does she have psychic powers or something?* Youngwoo grumbled but stood up. He grabbed the trash bag and headed for the door. Sunglasses went on. Face mask secured. *Millions of anti-fans because of Braham.* He hadn't checked social media in days. Didn't dare. The incident had probably exploded into a full-blown scandal by now. People loved to hate. Loved to tear down anyone who stood out. Better to stay hidden. Better to keep moving. He carried the trash to the curb and hurried back inside before anyone could recognize him.
